description: From Middle English schilling, shilling, from Old English sċilling, from Proto-Germanic *skillingaz, equivalent to skill +‎ -ing. Doublet of scalding.

entries.meaning: (historical) A coin formerly used in the United Kingdom, Ireland, Malta, Australia, New Zealand and many other Commonwealth countries worth twelve old pence, or one twentieth of a pound sterling.
examples: A great bargain also had been […] the arm-chair in which Bunting now sat forward, staring into the dull, small fire. In fact, that arm-chair had been an extravagance of Mrs. Bunting. She had wanted her husband to be comfortable after the day's work was done, and she had paid thirty-seven shillings for the chair.

entries.meaning: The currency of Kenya, Somalia, Tanzania and Uganda.
(US, historical) A currency in the United States, differing in value between states.
(US, historical, New York and some other states) The Spanish real, formerly having the value of one eighth of a dollar.
